title: اسم الإشارة للقريب: هَذَا
explanation: هَذَا is used to point to a masculine singular noun that is near. It means 'this'. Arabic has no verb 'is' in the present tense, so هَذَا كِتَابٌ means 'This is a book'.

title: التنوين
explanation: Tanween is the 'n' sound added to indefinite nouns. It appears as doubled vowel marks: ٌ (un), ً (an), ٍ (in). كِتَابٌ (kitaabun) means 'a book'. The ٌ indicates it's indefinite.

title: اسم الإشارة للبعيد: ذَلِكَ
explanation: ذَلِكَ is used to point to a masculine singular noun that is far. It means 'that'. Just like هَذَا, no verb 'is' is needed: ذَلِكَ نَجْمٌ means 'That is a star'.

title: الاستفهام بـ "مَا"
explanation: مَا means 'what' and is used to ask about things. The question مَا هَذَا؟ means 'What is this?' The answer uses the same structure: هَذَا كِتَابٌ (This is a book).

title: الاستفهام بـ "مَنْ"
explanation: مَنْ means 'who' and is used to ask about people. The question مَنْ هَذَا؟ means 'Who is this?' The answer identifies the person: هَذَا طَالِبٌ (This is a student).

title: الضمير المنفصل: هُوَ
explanation: هُوَ is the third person masculine singular pronoun meaning 'he'. It can replace a noun: هُوَ طَالِبٌ means 'He is a student'. It replaces هَذَا when referring to someone already mentioned.

title: اسم الإشارة للمؤنث: هَذِهِ
explanation: هَذِهِ is used to point to a feminine singular noun that is near. Arabic nouns have gender, and feminine nouns typically end in ة (taa marbuta). هَذِهِ سَيَّارَةٌ means 'This is a car'.

title: الضمير المنفصل: هِيَ
explanation: هِيَ is the third person feminine singular pronoun meaning 'she'. It's used for feminine nouns: هِيَ طَالِبَةٌ means 'She is a (female) student'.

title: اسم الإشارة للبعيد المؤنث: تِلْكَ
explanation: تِلْكَ is used to point to a feminine singular noun that is far. It means 'that' for feminine nouns. تِلْكَ مَدْرَسَةٌ means 'That is a school'.

title: التاء المربوطة
explanation: Most feminine nouns in Arabic end with ة (taa marbuta). This letter indicates feminine gender. When the noun has tanween, it sounds like 'tun': مَدْرَسَةٌ (madrasatun). Without tanween, it's silent: المَدْرَسَة (al-madrasa).

title: الإِضَافَة
explanation: Idaafa is how Arabic expresses possession. Two nouns are placed together: the possessed noun (mudaaf) loses its tanween and is followed by the possessor (mudaaf ilayhi) in the genitive case. كِتَابُ الطَّالِبِ means 'the student's book'.

title: الإِضَافَة مَعَ الضَّمَائِر
explanation: Possessive pronouns attach to the end of nouns. كِتَابِي means 'my book', كِتَابُكَ means 'your book'. The noun loses its tanween when a pronoun attaches.

title: حُرُوفُ الْجَرِّ
explanation: Prepositions in Arabic cause the following noun to be in the genitive case (majroor). Common prepositions include فِي (in), مِنْ (from), إِلَى (to), عَلَى (on), and مَعَ (with).

title: الصِّفَة
explanation: In Arabic, adjectives follow the noun they describe and must agree in gender, number, and definiteness. كِتَابٌ جَدِيدٌ means 'a new book'. Both words are indefinite (have tanween).

title: الْأَعْدَاد مِنْ 1-10
explanation: Arabic numbers 1-10 have special rules. Numbers 3-10 show reverse gender agreement: masculine nouns use feminine numbers. وَاحِدٌ and اِثْنَانِ agree normally with the noun.

title: الْفِعْلُ الْمَاضِي
explanation: Arabic past tense verbs are built from a three-letter root. The base form is third person masculine singular: كَتَبَ (he wrote), ذَهَبَ (he went). This form indicates completed actions.

title: تَصْرِيفُ الْفِعْلِ الْمَاضِي
explanation: Past tense verbs change endings based on the subject. ذَهَبْتُ (I went), ذَهَبْتَ (you m. went), ذَهَبَتْ (she went). The endings are suffixes attached to the verb root.

title: الْمُؤَنَّث
explanation: Feminine nouns typically end in ة (taa marbuta). Feminine verbs in the past tense add تْ: ذَهَبَتْ (she went). Adjectives become feminine by adding ة: كَبِيرَةٌ (big, fem.).

title: الْمُثَنَّى
explanation: Arabic has a special form for exactly two things. Add انِ for nominative: كِتَابَانِ (two books). Add يْنِ for genitive/accusative: كِتَابَيْنِ. The dual is used instead of the number two.

title: جَمْعُ الْمُذَكَّرِ السَّالِم وَجَمْعُ الْمُؤَنَّثِ السَّالِم
explanation: Sound masculine plural adds ونَ (nom.) or ينَ (gen./acc.): مُدَرِّسُونَ (teachers). Sound feminine plural replaces ة with اتٌ: طَالِبَاتٌ (female students). These are 'sound' because they follow regular patterns.

title: جَمْعُ التَّكْسِير
explanation: Many Arabic nouns form plurals by changing internal vowels (broken plurals). These must be memorized: كِتَابٌ → كُتُبٌ (books), بَيْتٌ → بُيُوتٌ (houses). They follow patterns like فُعُول and أَفْعَال.

title: الْفِعْلُ الْمُضَارِع
explanation: Present tense verbs indicate ongoing or future actions. They are formed by adding prefixes to the root: يَذْهَبُ (he goes/will go). The prefix indicates the subject: أَ (I), تَ (you), يَ (he), نَ (we).

title: تَصْرِيفُ الْفِعْلِ الْمُضَارِع
explanation: Present tense verbs change prefixes and sometimes suffixes: أَذْهَبُ (I go), تَذْهَبُ (you m. go), نَذْهَبُ (we go). The prefix indicates the person, and suffixes show gender/number.

title: أَدَوَاتُ النَّفْي
explanation: Arabic uses different particles for negation: لَا negates present tense (لَا يَذْهَبُ - he doesn't go), مَا negates past tense (مَا ذَهَبَ - he didn't go), لَيْسَ negates nominal sentences (لَيْسَ طَالِبًا - he is not a student).

title: الْجُمْلَة الْفِعْلِيَّة
explanation: A verbal sentence (جُمْلَة فِعْلِيَّة) begins with a verb. The typical order is Verb-Subject-Object: ذَهَبَ الطَّالِبُ (The student went). When the verb comes first, it stays singular even with plural subjects.

title: الْجُمْلَة الاسْمِيَّة
explanation: A nominal sentence (جُمْلَة اسْمِيَّة) begins with a noun (the subject/mubtada) followed by the predicate (khabar). No verb 'to be' is needed: الطَّالِبُ مُجْتَهِدٌ means 'The student is diligent'.

title: إِنَّ وَأَخَوَاتُهَا
explanation: إِنَّ and similar particles (أَنَّ، لَكِنَّ، لَعَلَّ) emphasize nominal sentences. They make the subject accusative (منصوب): إِنَّ الطَّالِبَ مُجْتَهِدٌ (Indeed, the student is diligent). The predicate remains nominative.

title: كَانَ وَأَخَوَاتُهَا
explanation: كَانَ (was) and similar verbs (أَصْبَحَ، صَارَ، لَيْسَ) modify nominal sentences for past or changed states. The subject stays nominative, but the predicate becomes accusative: كَانَ الطَّالِبُ مُجْتَهِدًا (The student was diligent).

title: الاستفهام بـ "أَيْنَ"
explanation: أَيْنَ means 'where' and is used to ask about location. It appears at the beginning of the question: أَيْنَ الْكِتَابُ؟ (Where is the book?). The answer typically uses a preposition like فِي.

title: الاستفهام بـ "مَتَى" و "كَيْفَ"
explanation: مَتَى means 'when' and asks about time: مَتَى جِئْتَ؟ (When did you come?). كَيْفَ means 'how' and asks about manner or state: كَيْفَ حَالُكَ؟ (How are you?).

title: الألوان
explanation: Arabic colors follow the pattern أَفْعَل for masculine (أَحْمَرُ - red) and فَعْلَاء for feminine (حَمْرَاءُ - red f.). They don't take tanween and are diptotes. Colors are adjectives that follow the noun they describe.

title: ظُرُوف الزَّمَان
explanation: Time adverbs indicate when an action occurs. Common ones include: الْيَوْمَ (today), غَدًا (tomorrow), أَمْسِ (yesterday), الآنَ (now). They typically come after the verb.

title: ظُرُوف الْمَكَان
explanation: Place adverbs indicate where something is located. Common ones include: هُنَا (here), هُنَاكَ (there), فَوْقَ (above), تَحْتَ (below), أَمَامَ (in front), وَرَاءَ (behind).

examples.english: The pen is on the table

title: أَدَوَات الرَّبْط
explanation: Arabic uses conjunctions to connect words and sentences. وَ (and) connects similar items, أَوْ (or) shows alternatives, ثُمَّ (then) shows sequence with delay, فَ (and/so) shows immediate sequence or result.

title: هَلْ وَالْهَمْزَة الاسْتِفْهَامِيَّة
explanation: هَلْ and أَ are used to form yes/no questions. هَلْ هَذَا كِتَابٌ؟ (Is this a book?). أَ is less common and attaches directly: أَهَذَا كِتَابٌ؟ The answer uses نَعَمْ (yes) or لَا (no).

title: الْمُضَاف وَالْمُضَاف إِلَيْهِ
explanation: In الإِضَافَة (genitive construction), the first noun (مُضَاف) is the possessed and loses tanween. The second (مُضَاف إِلَيْهِ) is the possessor and takes kasra. Both become definite even without الـ on the first.

title: أَنْوَاع الْجُمُوع
explanation: Arabic has three plural types: جَمْع سَالِم (sound) adds endings, جَمْع تَكْسِير (broken) changes internal pattern, and جَمْع قِلَّة (paucity) for 3-10 items. Most nouns have broken plurals that must be memorized.

title: الْجِنْس فِي الأَسْمَاء
explanation: Arabic nouns are either masculine or feminine. Feminine markers include: تَاء مَرْبُوطَة (ة), أَلِف مَقْصُورَة (ى), أَلِف مَمْدُودَة (اء). Some nouns are naturally feminine without markers (أُمّ، أَرْض).

title: الْفِعْل الْمُتَعَدِّي
explanation: Transitive verbs (الفعل المتعدي) require a direct object (مفعول به) to complete their meaning. The object takes the accusative case. Examples: كَتَبَ الدَّرْسَ (he wrote the lesson), أَكَلَ الطَّعَامَ (he ate the food).

title: الأَفْعَال الَّتِي تَنْصِب مَفْعُولَيْنِ
explanation: Some transitive verbs take two direct objects. These include verbs of giving (أَعْطَى), teaching (عَلَّمَ), and informing (أَخْبَرَ). Both objects are in the accusative case.

examples.english: The teacher gave the student a book
The professor taught the students grammar
The doctor asked the patient a question

title: الْفِعْل اللَّازِم
explanation: Intransitive verbs (الفعل اللازم) do not require a direct object to complete their meaning. They express complete actions on their own: ذَهَبَ (went), جَلَسَ (sat), نَامَ (slept).

title: الْفِعْل اللَّازِم مَعَ حُرُوف الْجَرّ
explanation: Intransitive verbs often take prepositional phrases to provide additional information. The preposition connects the verb to its complement indirectly.

title: الْمَفْعُول بِهِ
explanation: The direct object (المفعول به) is the noun that receives the action of the verb. It is always in the accusative case (منصوب). It answers 'what?' or 'whom?' after the verb.

title: ضَمَائِر الْمَفْعُول بِهِ
explanation: Object pronouns attach to the end of the verb to indicate the receiver of the action: ـهُ (him), ـهَا (her), ـكَ (you m.), ـنِي (me). These are the same suffixes used for possession.

title: حُرُوف الْجَرّ
explanation: Prepositions (حروف الجر) connect nouns to other elements in the sentence. Common prepositions: فِي (in), مِنْ (from), إِلَى (to), عَلَى (on), عَنْ (about), بِـ (with), لِـ (for).

title: حَالَة الْجَرّ
explanation: Nouns after prepositions take the genitive case (مجرور), shown by kasra. The genitive is also used in possessive constructions (الإضافة). Singular uses kasra, sound masculine plural uses ya (ين).

title: مُرَاجَعَة: أَسْمَاء الإِشَارَة وَالضَّمَائِر
explanation: Demonstratives point to nouns: هَذَا/هَذِهِ (this) and ذَلِكَ/تِلْكَ (that). Personal pronouns include: أَنَا (I), أَنْتَ (you m.), هُوَ (he), هِيَ (she), نَحْنُ (we), هُمْ (they).

title: مُرَاجَعَة: تَصْرِيف الأَفْعَال
explanation: Past tense verbs change endings based on the subject. Present tense verbs use prefixes and suffixes. Negation uses لَا (present), مَا (past), لَيْسَ (nominal).

title: الأَسْمَاء السِّتَّة - تَعْرِيف
explanation: الأسماء الستة are six special nouns: أَب (father), أَخ (brother), حَم (father-in-law), فَم (mouth), ذُو (possessor of), and هَن (a thing). They have unique case endings when possessed.

examples.english: He is a possessor of wealth

title: الأَسْمَاء السِّتَّة - شُرُوط الإِعْرَاب
explanation: For the six nouns to take special endings, they must be: singular, in genitive construction (مضاف), and the possessor cannot be ي (my). Without these conditions, they decline normally.

title: إِعْرَاب الأَسْمَاء السِّتَّة بِالْحُرُوف
titleEn: Case Endings of the Six Nouns
explanation: The six nouns show case through letters: nominative uses و (أَبُوكَ), accusative uses ا (أَبَاكَ), genitive uses ي (أَبِيكَ). These replace standard damma, fatha, kasra.

title: أَمْثِلَة عَلَى الأَسْمَاء السِّتَّة
explanation: The case of six nouns depends on grammatical function: subject (nominative/و), object (accusative/ا), after preposition (genitive/ي), and after إِنَّ (accusative/ا).

examples.english: Your brother is in the house
Indeed your father is a scholar

title: الاسْم الْمَقْصُور - تَعْرِيف
explanation: الاسم المقصور is a noun ending in unchangeable alif (ا or ى), like فَتًى (young man), هُدًى (guidance). All case endings are estimated on the alif.

examples.english: I saw the young man (acc. estimated)

title: الاسْم الْمَقْصُور - التَّثْنِيَة وَالْجَمْع
explanation: In dual, the alif changes to ي (فَتَيَانِ). Sound masculine plural drops the alif (مُصْطَفَوْنَ). Sound feminine plural changes alif to fatha before ات (فَتَيَاتٌ).

title: الاسْم الْمَنْقُوص - تَعْرِيف
explanation: الاسم المنقوص is a noun ending in ي preceded by kasra, like القَاضِي (judge). Nominative and genitive have estimated vowels; accusative has visible fatha.

title: الاسْم الْمَنْقُوص - التَّنْوِين
explanation: When indefinite with tanween, the ya is dropped in nominative/genitive (قَاضٍ), but kept in accusative (قَاضِيًا). The tanween replaces the dropped ya.

examples.english: He is a shepherd of sheep

title: الاسْم الْمَمْدُود - تَعْرِيف
explanation: الاسم الممدود is a noun ending in alif followed by hamza (اء), like السَّمَاء (sky). Unlike المقصور and المنقوص, it takes visible case endings on the hamza.

title: الاسْم الْمَمْدُود - أَنْوَاع الْهَمْزَة
explanation: The hamza can be original (أصلية), for feminization (للتأنيث), or transformed (منقلبة). Original stays in all forms. Feminization hamza changes to و in dual (صَحْرَاء → صَحْرَاوَانِ).
